narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 3: the out of class assignments were fun and taught a lot. I loved doing interviews and participant observation, but not so much surveys. I still think that while I didn't like doing surveys, they were worthwhile for my learning.

Professor Doolittle is exceptionally prepared for each lecture and willing to spend individual time developing student ideas. She provides concise, timely, and useful feedback on each project which is a great asset to any student.
Great class. I highly recommend it.
An absolutely essential course. Amity teaches it well and does a great job of making us feel prepared to go into the field, write proposals, get grants, and rock the world.
Question 9: We did outside research assignments, but I feel an outside group activity, done with surveying in the class would be beneficial.

Amity is a wonderful, engaging, and dynamic teacher and presenter. I looked forward to attending each class and to participating in discussions. It was a very thought-provoking class and I really appreciated that she actually taught us social science research methods, unlike the natural science research methods class, which I also took this past semester.

This was one of the most valuable courses I have ever taken. It gave me a concrete grounding in the theory and practical nature of social science research, and left me well prepared to begin my MESc research. I cannot say enough good things about the clarity with which Amity teaches, the attention she and Roopa paid to the practical aspects of narrowing a research question, understanding theory and methodology, and developing a proposal. The course was basic and clear without holding my hand, and I left with a feeling of accomplishment and confidence about writing proposals to apply for funding.
Open discussion, letting the class decide what they wanted to work on the most.
Activities to practice developing research methods in relation to individual research problems
Field Exercises
Writing a proposal as the final paper, and very clear explanations of how to structure a research project.
Amity's lectures.
The goal of writing the proposal for the summer research and how to analyze field data qualitatively.
The instructor was very engaging.
The opportunity to focus on a specific area of interest and prepare a proposal.

We had a lot of assignments that focused on putting things into practice, and the course had a very pragmatic focus in terms of aiming for a research proposal at the end. This was much more helpful than any purely theoretical treatment would have been.

1. The instructor2. The opportunity to learn about social science research methods3. The opportunity to break into groups and discuss our research4. The flexibility of the syllabus5. The chance to go out into the public and do observations and interviews6. Amity provided feedback on our papers in a respectable amount of time
Assignments to explore methods from readings. Feedback form professor and other students.

Amity's responsiveness and clear teaching style. The out of class assignments (observation, survey, etc) were very valuable and the structure of the course built very well towards producing a final proposal.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The lectures seemed a bit rapid-fire at times.

Discussion sections did not give everyone equal time to explore their projects. Students who came in with the most clearly developed projects were able to refine their projects, while it was difficult to explore new or potential research ideas.
NA

Group time spent on proposals wasn't always the most efficient. It felt like the same people kept asking for their proposals to be looked over, and a lot of people missed out and didn't get much time spent on their proposals as a result.
Maybe we don't need to purchase any texts?
It would have been nice if this course was three hours on one day instead of split between the two days.

Sometimes the course became a bit unstructured. Sometimes we had too much time to discuss our projects in groups. It was definitely helpful to do that, but after discussing for awhile I think a lot of people felt like they needed to stop, go back and do some more legwork on their own before they could then return and continue a productive discussion.
1. The lectures were rushed and it was hard to follow at times, especially when jumping back and forth between slides.
Perhaps add a lesson on using Endnote or Ref Works next year.

While they ended up being quite valuable, the field assignments themselves were initially unclear with regards to expectations and desired write up. It would have been good if right from the beginning Amity had said "the guidelines on these projects are deliberately vague so that you can use them to prepare for your research however you think best, but I am providing some structure in case you're not ready to strike out on your own yet."

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Contacted instructor--very helpful. Always helping you conceptualize your research.
Excellent
I receive the help I needed from both parties
Both were very available and helpful.

Excellent. I really appreciate Amity's sign-up sheet for office hours. It makes it very clear to us when her office hours are, and by signing up for them, holds us accountable to go in and talk to her when we said we would.
Anytime, and good quality.
The TA was good but she was not very conversant with the core of research. But, she was very helpful as she did her best to make sure that everyone is comfortable in class.
Both were great
Both were very available and helpful.
Professor Doolittle and the TA were both available when needed, and their advice was generally very helpful.

Both the professor and the TA were very willing and able to meet with students. Professor Doolittle was very helpful in office hours discussions. I did not meet with Roopa, but she was very helpful in terms of setting up a forum for people to comment on each others presentations at the end.
Amity had posted office hours, but always seemed to be in a hurry when meeting and speaking with her.Roopa was always available and willing to help out, which I greatly appreciated.

Both the TA and the instructor for this course went above and beyond in terms of support outside of class. The TA organized a gathering outside of class to help students feel more comfortable with each other to encourage more discussion and feedback in class.The instructor held regular office hours for students and responded immediately to emails. Holding regular office hours might not sound that special, but there are some professors at FES that students literally have to track and hunt down if they want to talk to them. The professor was very willing to meet with students and I found my discussions with her to be very helpful.
Terrific. I worked with both several times and received their full attention and great advice.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: MEMs don't need this course, so it doesn't really fit in. But for me, it was so beneficial personally to learn how how to structure a research project from start to finish.
Anyone who is planning on conduction qualitative research now or in the future will find this a useful way of improving their methodology and proposals
This course is different and a bit unrelated but the skills gained are invaluable.
MESc social science req.
I think we need to know methods of social science research, period.
This course is unlike anything I have ever taken before.
My career will involve working with people as well as with the natural world, so an understanding of social science methodology is really important.

This course was a necessity for my social ecology program, but I was not very familiar with social science methods and the pros/cons of them. I really wish that the two methods classes would be combined for students with intersdisciplinary research and interests.

Really well. As I said above, before this course I felt unprepared to begin research-- I didn't know my topic, didn't know how to begin, what to do, where to get funding, or how to talk about research. The course taught me ALL of that.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I considered switching to MeSc
I took it to get a better understanding of when and why to use certain research methods (interviews vs. surveys, qualitative vs. quantitative, etc).
MESc social science req.
MESc. requirement and to make sure I knew what I as doing for my fieldwork--proper methodology.
MESc
To gain training in research methods.
I wanted the structure it gave me to find and develop a research project.

See above (question 15)... also, I had no prior background in this, so it was especially critical for me to establish a foundation. I was also interested in exploring the possibility of doing research, so this was a great forum for doing that.
I took this course because I heard that Amity was a great teacher, and I thought it would be beneficial for my research project.
Well, it was required, and I planned for my research to be more about "people," so I was steered towards Qualitative rather than Quantitative.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
My expectations were exceeded
Yes
I learned way more than I expected to.
yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes

Yes, I had the opportunity to practice many of the elements of social science research, and to debate their relative merits and limitations. I also enjoyed the opportunity to collaborate with others, to comment on others' work and to receive advice on my own project.
Yes.
It far exceeded them.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
yes plus some
Yes
Learned more
Yes--a good review too of the work already done with learning theory!
Yes
Yes.
Yes
See above (question 17)
Yes.
Yes (see above)

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to feedback and ideas from students
See above.
Group work is like flipping a coin. Sometimes you get something out of it, and sometimes you don't. Sometimes it's productive, and sometimes it's not.
We often broke into groups in order to discuss our projects. This was very helpful and interesting.
Advantage: peer feedback.Disadvantage: sometimes a little uncertain of how to proceed with small group discussions.

Different work groups each week...they were valuable and I appreciated receiving my classmates' advice and input, but sometimes felt that we spent too much time workshopping and could have used a bit more all-class guidance on writing and thinking through research questions.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't stress about having the perfect research question right away. The course allows for a lot of time to figure it out. In fact, your question will probably change anyway over the course.

This course clearly lays out and reviews methods for social science and qualitative research. It will help you to design summer research or a future research project. If you are uncertain what you will be doing this summer, make sure to actively seek out other students who are willing to help you develop your ideas during discussion sections and work on developing methodology for the specific project later in the semester.
read what you need

I would recommend taking advantage ofthe opportunity to get great feedback on your research throughout the semester. Experiment with different methods and approaches -- the class is really useful even if (or especially if) you're having trouble deciding on a project or proposal topic.
Come into the course knowing what you want to study! Talk with your adviser early about what you'll be doing this summer.
Take it.
Have fun.

Have a clear idea of the research you want to conduct before, or by the beginning, of class. It's not necessary, but it will make the class much more useful. If you want to come out with a proposal ready to submit for funding, start early.
Definitely take this course if you are considering research. Definitely take this course if you plan to work with people and communities and you have no prior background in the social sciences.

Amity is a great professor. If you are doing interdisciplinary research and are thinking about taking both methods classes, take Amity's for sure, but take the other one as well only if it has a different teacher next time.

Don't take advantage of Amity's kindness, but do pay attention and do the work (which is not too excessive at all), and you'll end up with a much better understanding of how to perform research, especially if you haven't done it before.
